This weekend edition from NPR News I'm Scott Simon officials in Florida scrambling to get food and water to residents are communities that were hit hard by hurricane Michael here's bay county sheriff spokesperson Ruth correlate speaking yesterday to member station WBUR K juicy
We're working on getting water here we are working on getting food here they need to let these people are working very hard to determine where do we start to repair it and so we can have wider again so that our toilets will flash well working on getting port a potty that we understand the basic needs
Hundreds of thousands are without power from the Florida Panhandle into Virginia the storm is now blamed for at least fourteen debts NPR's Joel Rose in Miramar Beach Florida Joel thanks for being with us Hi Scott what is the situation seem like today well
Do you mentioned there are lots of folks without power and the situation seems particularly dire in Panama City and some of the smaller towns in Bay county along the Gulf of Mexico
There in Panama City there's no water no power no gas most gas stations are still closed 'em and and as you head out of town to find the stations do have gas or very long lines
Many folks have evacuated from this region but for those who stayed behind it's getting increasingly difficult just to find
The city about thirty seven thousand residents 'em before the storm on it's on the bay it's not directly on the Gulf of Mexico that's not a luxurious town I mean the houses are set pretty close together
And right now it's like every block is is um almost like a scene from a disaster movie like their trees down there are wires in the street seems like every buildings to stay in some kind of damage
Or either to the roof or to the wall I mean I saw a church that was missing two of its walls and and you could just be from the pews right out into the the blue sky outside um churches schools public buildings hospitals all of this at this day and a lot of damage a and I think it's starting to really dawned on folks to this is going to be a very long recovery
Right now fourteen the debt strip fourteen people have been reported and confirmed but I gather nobody there are things such as that the final word
Unfortunately no I mean I I think people do think that the death toll is likely to rise up so far officials here have been pretty tight lipped they don't want to release numbers until they finished the search and rescue process a bay county emergency chief mark ... was asked yesterday about the number of fatalities here's what he said
What we have is a lot of people missing I Want to be very careful about numbers because are they missing because their loved ones can't contact them or are they missing because they were you know perished in the store
And when you said loved ones are missing or can contact them it's a it's true that cell phones are not working very well not only in Panama City but all over the county so it remains really difficult to communicate and find relatives who may have stayed behind in the storm
But still you do get the feeling that the number of fatalities is going to go up and maybe way up when we start to get more information from the waterfront communities or you know to the south and east of Panama City places like Springfield Parker mess

Pope Francis accepted the resignation of Washington DC is cardinal Donald Wuerl over his role in covering up two different church sexual abuse scandals the first
In Pennsylvania was detailed and a nine hundred page report in August that outlines sexually abused by priests in six dioceses over which were presided he was also accused of covering up allegations against his predecessor D.C.'s cardinal Theodore ... character who resigned from the College of cardinals earlier this year [noise]
These are unsettling time for many of us Catholics no ... is the young man who grow up in Pennsylvania and one of Donald worlds diocese and moved to Washington DC this summer he joins us from Washington DC thanks so much for being with us yeah it's good to be here
Tell us about your faith which which made you a Roman Catholic
Well up until this point in my life is all I had really known as far as religion goes I I Believe and
Most of what I was taught growing up um it always resonated with me the messages that they present to the congregation I think that having a faith has made me a better person and I think it has not effect on a lot of people
How did you feel when you found out there's some are about the abuse of children that was going on in Pennsylvania ... not far from places you knew
It hurt reading the report because I was reading about these parasites that I went to growing up I was born in Ninety
... anything behind that I just sort of thought it was people making fun of her religion
And then I didn't learn honestly until recently that the abuse scandal is something that was real and something that the world is known about than what I think it was the early to thousands whenever the Boston Globe or whatever the newspaper is broke the story I I didn't know that that was a thing
It wasn't something I'd ever been exposed to so I wasn't really aware of the fact that this is a problem that was going on in my church you know it's it's on ...
And a church or face

Thing to answer I Will say that it has hurt my face in the Catholic Church I don't think it is actually hurt my personal religious faith I'm just starting to see less of a connection between what I Believe and the teaching of the Catholic Church
Man did you grow up with anyone do you know anyone who uh who has their own story to do no I Do not fortunately
Nothing like that ever happened to me or anybody I was close with
Do you think the church cared more about itself as an institution and less about the people who had been harmed
It certainly seems like that to me and that's one of the most disheartening things about it I Do not think that the church leadership has done enough to make up for
The release of disabuse seeing bishops been people whose names are plastered up on church building
Back in my area hearing that they spent years pushing this stuff away and covering it all up just to save the good name of the church I suppose instead of actually trying to make up for
The heartbreaking abused there was actually occurring to me it it it feels like church leadership was more
Interested in preserving their own good name
I Am and that's what I've been struggling with because of the Catholic Church is is all I ever was involved and growing up so recently over the past few months
I'm moving to a new area of starting a new a new part of my life and times the breaking of abuse new stories I've been exploring other options I Do still believe in God I still have a faith and I just much less of the connection between my personal faith and the Catholic Church

Reporters got a rare glimpse inside a temporary shelter for migrant children in far west Texas on friday the facility opened in June as a series of huge chance on a remote stretch of desert just north of the Mexican border its capacity has rapidly expanded since then can help contain
Up to thirty eight hundred children Monica Ortiz Uribe it tells us what's driving the need for more shelters based and what it's like an shot

What I Would call like shards of abuse and you know and I was around on it and she started to uh with me when I didn't do right and she would always say she was looking at me because when I was faced with police why people would be even a harsher
